commit_message:
Raise conflict exception on RP create 409

Per design [1], we want consumers of SchedulerReportClient to be able to
detect placement API conflict errors (HTTP 409), as distinct from other
errors.  Such consumers (the resource tracker) may respond to conflicts
by redriving the operation in progress, whereas other exceptions will be
allowed to bubble up.

In this change set, we introduce a new exception class,
PlacementAPIConflict, which will be the (base) class of exception raised
in response to placement 409s for which we want to allow this kind of
behavior.   We also update the _create_resource_provider helper in
SchedulerReportClient to do just that, raising
ResourceProviderCreateConflict (a subclass of the above) as appropriate.

Subsequent changes will implement similar behavior for other conflicts,
such as those caused by generation mismatches when updating provider
associations (traits, aggregates, etc.).

Ultimately, the resource tracker will trap PlacementAPIConflict while
attempting to sync placement from ComputeDriver.update_provider_tree,
and will respond by reinvoking that method and retrying the sync
operation.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova_scheduler/2018/nova_scheduler.2018-01-08-14.00.log.html#l-251

Change-Id: If1661900c14ef6c4fe29ecc67c04f741003a5318
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/63/532563/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Raise a 'Conflict' exception on 409. Callers will often respond to # conflicts by redriving the operation. if resp.status_code == 409: raise exception.ResourceProviderCreateConflict( name=name, uuid=uuid, error=resp.text) # Generic exception for any other error.

subject: [libvirt] Allow multiple volume attachments
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-01-14 14:08:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8749b1d73a742bb2bcdd6cc0f312fddedcd2bcb7', 'message': "comp: Allow volume multiattach

Modify check_attach to accept multiple volume attachments. The patch
also allows to create multiple BDMs for a single volume.

The patch blocks booting from existing multiattach enabled volume by checking
the 'source_type' and 'destination_type' to be volume and 'boot_index'
to be zero in block_device_map.

APIImpact This patch allows to attach a volume to multiple VM instances
if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume

This patch allows in the compute manager to attach a volume to multiple
VM instances if the 'multiattach' flag on the volume is set to true.

The change is needed as when we enable the 'multiattach' support in the API
in Newton in a mixed environment where we have both Mitaka and Newton
compute services the feature will work in the entire environment in a
homogen way depending on the API microversion.

Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
"}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2016-01-28 09:47:41.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8f43881ec1abeea583990e82f294d1eac3613d52', 'message': "libvirt: Allow multiple volume attachments

Add multiattach support to libvirt driver, by updating the
xml configuration info if the multiattach support is turned
on for a volume and set the virt driver capability
'support_multiattach' to true. This capability is set to false
for all the other drivers.

Also the attach function in nova/virt/block_device.py is updated
to call out to Cinder in case of each attachment request for
multiattach volumes, which is needed for Cinder in order to track
all attachments for a volume and be able to detach properly.

Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b

xml configuration info if the multiattach support is turned
on for a volume and set the virt driver capability
'support_multiattach' to true. This capability is set to false
for all the other drivers.

Also the attach function in nova/virt/block_device.py is updated
to call out to Cinder in case of each attachment request for
multiattach volumes, which is needed for Cinder in order to track
all attachments for a volume and be able to detach properly.

Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b

commit_message:
[libvirt] Allow multiple volume attachments

Add multiattach support to libvirt driver, by updating the
xml configuration info if the multiattach support is turned
on for a volume and set the virt driver capability
'support_multiattach' to true. This capability is set to false
for all the other drivers.

Also the attach function in nova/virt/block_device.py is updated
to call out to Cinder in case of each attachment request for
multiattach volumes, which is needed for Cinder in order to track
all attachments for a volume and be able to detach properly.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Partially-implements: blueprint multi-attach-volume
Change-Id: I947bf0ad34a48e9182a3dc016f47f0c9f71c9d7b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/87/267587/80 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: if new_volume['attach_status'] == 'attached': msg = _("New volume must be detached in order to swap.") raise exception.InvalidVolume(reason=msg)

commit_message:
fixed Unused views in Network Topology

Before this was fixed users could navigate to and be redirected
to these pages which serve no purpose other then that their urls
are used for delete operations. I have changed the code so
that the user is automatically redirected to the network_topology/index.
Because of this users will not find themselves on a page which is
useless for them and a page that they can not navigate out of
unless they use the back button.

Change-Id: Ia715075460446fc73175ac44bec144a029f633de
Fixes-Bug: #1718666

commit_message:
Update security group rule protocol parameter text

Updated text to include "any"/"0" and "ipip"/"4" as
valid parameters for protocol in security group rules,
as well as any integer value from [0-255].

Change-Id: I80ee9bcd885c5c0383925f8d0bb10d34335f8038
Related-bug: #1716790
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lib refs/changes/62/534962/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Valid string or integer values are ``any`` or ``0``, ``ah`` or ``51``, ``dccp`` or ``33``, ``egp`` or ``8``, ``esp`` or ``50``, ``gre`` or ``47``, ``icmp`` or ``1``, ``icmpv6`` or ``58``, ``igmp`` or ``2``, ``ipip`` or ``4``, ``ipv6-encap`` or ``41``, ``vrrp`` or ``112``. Additionally, any integer value between [0-255] is also valid. The string ``any`` (or integer ``0``) means ``all`` IP protocols. See the constants in ``neutron_lib.constants`` for the most up-to-date list of supported strings.
deleted_lines: Valid string or integer values are ``ah`` or ``51``, ``dccp`` or ``33``, ``egp`` or ``8``, ``esp`` or ``50``, ``gre`` or ``47``, ``icmp`` or ``1``, ``icmpv6`` or ``58``, ``igmp`` or ``2``, ``ipv6-encap`` or ``41``, ``vrrp`` or ``112``.

commit_message:
Add per_volume attributes for volume

Swift requires uuid to be created per volume, allow
definition of per volume parameters for partitions.

Closes-bug: #1653305
Change-Id: Iffcaa07b2db2e477d373b12aca76e523fb6a7c5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/19/415919/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_per_volume_for_partition(self): node = self.create_node('ceph-osd') v = filter(lambda v: v['id'] == 'ceph', node.cluster.release.volumes_metadata['volumes'])[0] v['per_volume'] = {'fs_uuid': {'generator': 'uuid'}} self.env.db.flush() volumes = [i for s in node.volume_manager.gen_volumes_info() for i in s['volumes'] if i.get('name') == 'ceph'] for v in volumes: self.assertIn('fs_uuid', v) self.assertEqual(len(v['fs_uuid']), 36)

commit_message:
Kilo: Install ceilometermiddleware from requirements

If ceilometermiddleware is installed based not on global requirements,
it retrieves one of the latest WebOb.

WebOb>=1.7.1 (from oslo.messaging>=4.0.0->ceilometermiddleware)

One of the problems it leads to, is images in glance being in "queued"
state after they are uploaded.

Change-Id: I3c623c33afe4d5ffb87a1881bdf9393bde85ec03
Related-bug: #1657452
Related-bug: #1657459

commit_message:
Fix openstackdocstheme options for api-ref

Initialize the parameter for current openstackdocstheme so that report a
bug feature works and displays all parameter including git URL and SHA.

We need to add openstackdocstheme as extension so that the parameter are
properly initialized. html_context is not needed anymore. The display of
time of last commit is done by openstackdocstheme.

Change-Id: Ic46f5ff6bc42b48ce9de5f5bf3a2193ed75fb063
Closes-Bug: #1743728

commit_message:
Add OS_DEBUG to passenv of tox

There is currently no way of passing the OS_DEBUG variable to
tests triggered by tox. It seems this variable was lost in a
migration. This patch adds it again.

Change-Id: I3c156e899d75f7f10e9b44b1abafce922b57b891

commit_message:
Don't truncate subnetpools from subnet filters.

update subnet truncate allocation pools from subnet data
due to filters in networking-odl, this patch fixes the
update subnet filters and add unit testcases to assert
allocation pools in subnet data of journal.

[odl-bug]. https://jira.opendaylight.org/browse/NETVIRT-955

Co-Authored-By: Manjeet Singh Bhatia<manjeet.s.bhatia@intel.com>

Change-Id: I638bad86e0d183f6629729144ba653525897c31e

subject: Swap the order of stdout and stderr in debug output
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-18 13:31:41.000000000', 'files': ['common/deploy-steps-tasks.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/56448dafeda8db1916b2a65fd19bd70c7e6ff176', 'message': "Swap the order of stdout and stderr in debug output

Generally this data is looked at because something failed, and in
that case the relevant error is likely to be at the end of stderr.
By concatenating the output stderr first and then stdout as we were
it is possible for the stderr to get lost entirely in the failures
list, and even if that doesn't happen it's best to output the
relevant error right at the end of the output where people will
see it.  Previously it would be buried in the middle of the debug
output.

Closes-bug: #1743754

Change-Id: I952fd1af5778ade1eb6b0599d983f98cadeb7f6f
(cherry picked from commit 5595e7fc14430ee0636060afc82f909d4b3d04be)
"}]
commit_message:
Swap the order of stdout and stderr in debug output

Generally this data is looked at because something failed, and in
that case the relevant error is likely to be at the end of stderr.
By concatenating the output stderr first and then stdout as we were
it is possible for the stderr to get lost entirely in the failures
list, and even if that doesn't happen it's best to output the
relevant error right at the end of the output where people will
see it.  Previously it would be buried in the middle of the debug
output.

Closes-bug: #1743754

Change-Id: I952fd1af5778ade1eb6b0599d983f98cadeb7f6f
(cherry picked from commit 5595e7fc14430ee0636060afc82f909d4b3d04be)

commit_message:
Log as error failure to send to Kafka

Exception on failure to send to Kafka was only being logged
at the debug level. Increased to error level as this is a major
failure in the Threshold Engine functionality

Change-Id: I131d6d7a20cd0e907334cf5d0ff6fac342e8f320

subject: log-api: Don't enable logging for linuxbridge
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-18 13:52:20.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/contrib/gate_hook.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4db37df648adeb425d6dcc21138dae74e8558e5a', 'message': "log-api: Don't enable logging for linuxbridge

We still run API tests agains logging API and the job has OVS enabled.
As all linuxbridge flavors contain same string, this patch changes when
logging service plugin is configured which is always but in linuxbridge
scenario job.

commit_message:
log-api: Don't enable logging for linuxbridge

We still run API tests agains logging API and the job has OVS enabled.
As all linuxbridge flavors contain same string, this patch changes when
logging service plugin is configured which is always but in linuxbridge
scenario job.

Change-Id: I66234f45ee74c070119d84830790df296ba8d5f7
Related-bug: #1743463

commit_message:
RedHat: Ensure that conflicting MariaDB packages are removed

When the galera_server role is deployed along with other roles, some
of them may pull mariadb packages as a dependency for the services
they deploy. However, this role uses MariaDB packages from the upstream
repository which conflict with those provided by the EPEL or the RDO
ones so we need to ensure that they are gone before we install the
upstream ones.

Change-Id: Ie800c1f4628eff24954f392fe6318206adfabddb
Closes-Bug: #1742206
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-galera_server refs/changes/19/534819/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Conflicting packages with those from the MariaDB repository galera_server_mariadb_distro_packages_remove: - mariadb-common - mariadb-config - mariadb-server - mariadb-libs

commit_message:
Really open cinder-specs for Rocky

The previous commit to open cinder-specs for Rocky
doesn't appear to have worked:
2353d9a0d5dd24ae9d0b61c847fd21aad51ea012

It appears that just putting .gitignore in the directory
doesn't cause git to actually create the directory. I can see
that the patch merged but the directory doesn't appear in
subsequent pulls of cinder-specs.  Going back to the
method of using .placeholder here.

Change-Id: Ib94315f73f59aa9c3910731d6c166d6b020bf65c

commit_message:
Restore the default semantics of refresh()

It's fair to expect refresh() to actually refresh the resource, and that's
how it works in the previous release. This change flips the default
value of the newly introduced "force" argument to keep this behavior.

Change-Id: Ib50d7e52b76899bb6eb1ef1c5096bcb6f7a477a6

Note that its # subresources won't be marked as stale, and thus they won't be refreshed by # a call to refresh(force=False) sys_inst.invalidate()

commit_message:
Improve object-updater's stats logging

The object updater has five different stats, but its logging only told
you two of them (successes and failures), and it only told you after
finishing all the async_pendings for a device. If you have a cluster
that's been sick and has millions upon millions of async_pendings
laying around, then your object-updaters are frustratingly
silent. I've seen one cluster with around 8 million async_pendings per
disk where the object-updaters only emitted stats every 12 hours.

Yes, if you have StatsD logging set up properly, you can go look at
your graphs and get real-time feedback on what it's doing. If you
don't have that, all you get is a frustrating silence.

Now, the object updater tells you all of its stats (successes,
failures, quarantines due to bad pickles, unlinks, and errors), and it
tells you incremental progress every five minutes. The logging at the
end of a pass remains and has been expanded to also include all stats.

Also included is a small change to what counts as an error: unmounted
drives no longer do. The goal is that only abnormal things count as
errors, like permission problems, malformed filenames, and so
on. These are things that should never happen, but if they do, may
require operator intervention. Drives fail, so logging an error upon
encountering an unmounted drive is not useful.

Change-Id: Idbddd507f0b633d14dffb7a9834fce93a10359ab
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/07/533207/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: make_timestamp_iter, debug_logger, patch_policies, mocked_http_conn, FakeLogger) def test_sweep_logs(self): asyncdir = os.path.join(self.sda1, ASYNCDIR_BASE) prefix_dir = os.path.join(asyncdir, 'abc') mkpath(prefix_dir) for o, t in [('abc', 123), ('def', 234), ('ghi', 345), ('jkl', 456), ('mno', 567)]: ohash = hash_path('account', 'container', o) o_path = os.path.join(prefix_dir, ohash + '-' + normalize_timestamp(t)) write_pickle({}, o_path) class MockObjectUpdater(object_updater.ObjectUpdater): def process_object_update(self, update_path, device, policy): os.unlink(update_path) self.stats.successes += 1 self.stats.unlinks += 1 logger = FakeLogger() ou = MockObjectUpdater({ 'devices': self.devices_dir, 'mount_check': 'false', 'swift_dir': self.testdir, 'interval': '1', 'concurrency': '1', 'stats_log_interval': '10.0', 'node_timeout': '5'}, logger=logger) now = [time()] def mock_time_function(): rv = now[0] now[0] += 5 return rv # With 10s between updates, time() advancing 5s every time we look, # and 5 async_pendings on disk, we should get at least two progress # lines. with mock.patch('swift.obj.updater.time', mock.MagicMock(time=mock_time_function)): ou.object_sweep(self.sda1) info_lines = logger.get_lines_for_level('info') self.assertEqual(4, len(info_lines)) self.assertIn("sweep starting", info_lines[0]) self.assertIn(self.sda1, info_lines[0]) self.assertIn("sweep progress", info_lines[1]) # the space ensures it's a positive number self.assertIn(" 2 successes", info_lines[1]) self.assertIn(self.sda1, info_lines[1]) self.assertIn("sweep progress", info_lines[2]) self.assertIn(" 4 successes", info_lines[2]) self.assertIn(self.sda1, info_lines[2]) self.assertIn("sweep complete", info_lines[3]) self.assertIn(" 5 successes", info_lines[3]) self.assertIn(self.sda1, info_lines[3])

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-18 14:01:27.000000000', 'files': ['tests/test-containers-functional.yml', 'tests/host_vars/container2.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create/commit/887ebaa3ce4538f495729defee65bfde3f1bba05', 'message': "tests: Set lxc-openstack apparmor profile when overlayfs is used

The overlayfs backing store doesn't play well with the unconfined
profile and many tools (eg ping, traceroute) are failing to work

As such, lets switch to the lxc-openstack profile is overlayfs is used

commit_message:
tests: Set lxc-openstack apparmor profile when overlayfs is used

The overlayfs backing store doesn't play well with the unconfined
profile and many tools (eg ping, traceroute) are failing to work
with the following error:

ping: error while loading shared libraries: libcap.so.2: cannot stat
shared object: Permission denied

As such, lets switch to the lxc-openstack profile is overlayfs is used
as the backing store.

Change-Id: Ibe1149ee4fedd2b3d487887e504c500c96165467
Related-Bug: #1612412
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create refs/changes/33/535333/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The unconfined profile is causing problems with overlayfs. See https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1612412 - "lxc.aa_profile={{ (lxc_container_backing_store == 'overlayfs') | ternary('lxc-openstack', 'unconfined') }}"

commit_message:
Split IPSEC deployment in two

The first phase sets up the node-to-node tunnels at step 1; this
ensures that the corosync cluster setup is done over the tunnels
and prevents any timeouts that were happening when the setup was
done after the cluster was up. This has the added value that all
the pacemaker communication is encrypted from the beginning.

The second phase is the VIP tunnel setup, which is in step 3. This
is because we need the VIPs to be setup by pacemaker, and we also
need pacemaker to be up.

Depends-On: Ib9a134648c74e5dfcbd7a8ebd2d67bda87992497
Change-Id: Ic402dc73044e2426b097ed0eaf57a77c5e6eef24

commit_message:
Add spec for ELK stack in openstack-ansible

* With edits and clarifications
* Addional edits, formatting and redo the links

Change-Id: Ib08c7a6e3cb229c81f4c65aba856ec01db359c1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-specs refs/changes/69/527769/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ELK Stack ################################# :date: 2017-12-11 11:00 :tags: logging, monitoring, operations Blueprint on Launchpad: * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+spec/elk-stack Log file analysis is an important part of maintaining and troubleshooting OpenStack clouds, but using traditional single server methodology to analyze the logs on clouds with tens, hundreds or thousands of servers can become problematic and unwieldy. By leveraging the search, collation and analysis features of the ELK (Elasticsearch[*]_, Logstash[*]_ and Kibana[*]_) stack we can provide a cloud level view of all of the log files. The ELK stack also provides the ability to correlate log messages across various services, perform detailed log analysis and do trending based on metrics derived from log messages. Problem description =================== For deployers and operators findings specific events in the myriad log files produced by the various OpenStack, system and ancillary services can be tedious and error prone. With traditional tools the possibility of missing critical log entries grows as the size of the cluster increases. Log file analysis provides vital information about the state of the OpenStack services as well as the underlying hardware. Currently there are no tools provided by OpenStack-Ansible to detailed log analysis, correlation and trending. Proposed change =============== Utilizing the logging/utility node we install the ELK stack in containers, logs are shipped from the individual nodes/containers using the Filebeats package. Using Filebeats to perform the initial log shipping allows us to do initial multiline parsing distributing the load away from a single Logstash container. Notable changes: * Create elasticsearch, logstash, kibana containers on the logging/utility node. * Install the Filebeats package on all nodes/containers Alternatives ------------ Logs are currently shipped to a centralized rsyslog-server container on the logging/utility server allowing for some sort of centralized log parsing using command line utilities. There are other 3rd party solutions with various levels of cost, adoption and support. Playbook/Role impact -------------------- The changes required are located in stand alone playbooks. Additional roles will need to be created for Logstash, Kibana and Filebeats, the `ansible-elasticsearch`[*]_ maintained by elastic.co provides Elasticsearch. Configuration can be stand-alone or integrated into the `user-variables.yml` and `user-secrets.yml` files. Upgrade impact -------------- As this is the initial implementation there is no upgrade impact. Future versions will require upgrade planning as it may be necessary to upgrade versions of the ELK packages, OpenJDK packages and possibly the Elasticsearch database itself. Security impact --------------- This software provides a web based front end as well as API access to any information contained in the Openstack, service and system logs that are shipped to it. As such it will need to be only visible to authenicated users. All ccess can be secured through the traditional hardening that is applied to any standard web service. Furthermore we can limit access to certain IPs and/or networks via a number of ACLs. Performance impact ------------------ Based on testing and real-world analysis the largest performance impact will be on the logging/utility server. As this devices original intent was to perform log processing this is expected and not unusual. The filebeats service running in each node/container has demonstrated a negligible impact. Elastic.co is the maintainer of all of the software other than Java, which is maintained by Oracle corporation. Both of these entities provide enterprise software and thus follow strict release schedules and have reliable upstream repositories for their software. End user impact --------------- End users should not notice the changes from this work. This is primarily intended for deployers and operators. This change does give operations teams more insight into the environment and will hopefully facilitate a more performant and stable deployment. Deployer impact --------------- The ELK stack is an optional component and does not directly interact with any Openstack services. All of the ELK packages are provided via apt/yum repositories. An additional secret will need to be created for the `kibana` user. The filebeats package will be installed in all containers and on all nodes but it is extremely lightweight, with configuration stored in `/etc/filebeat`. Java is required for ELK so the `openjdk` or JDK implementation of the deployers choosing will need to be installed in three containers on the logging/utility node. Developer impact ---------------- This should be a minimal change for developers, the one thing that they will need to keep in mind is if additional log files are added they will need to be added to the filebeat configuration, this can be handled by re-running the filebeat play against the containers with the new logs. Dependencies ------------ There are no dependencies. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary Assignee: David Wilde (d34dh0r53) Work items ---------- 1. Create ELK and filebeats roles in openstack-ansible or openstack-ansible-ops 2. Create playbook(s) to install the ELK stack and filebeats 3. Create testing procedures for the stack 4. Document Testing ======= The ELK stack should be tested on each commit by ensuring that the services start and that logs are flowing into the system and being parsed correctly. This can be acomplished by injecting a line into a services log file and then using the elasticsearch API via curl to verify that the line was correctly inserted into the database with the expected fields parsed. Documentation impact ==================== Along with the general installation procedures and configuration the key points of documentation will be: * Filebeats parsing rules * Logstash parsing rules * Kibana dashboard configuration * The default Kibana dashboard References ========== [*] https://elastic.co/products/elasticearch [*] https://elastic.co/products/logstash [*] https://elastic.co/products/kibana [*] https://github.com/elastic/ansible-elasticsearch

commit_message:
Fix BadRequest for 'ref' as string value

Before schema validation patch [1] got merged, it was allowed to
pass "ref" as string value (ref:"string") in request body of
snapshot_manage create API but after schema changes, it is
returning 400 error.

This patch fixes this issue by allowing user to pass "ref" parameter
as string.

Note: In case user uses python-cinderclient to manage snapshot, it
always passes "ref" parameter as object (dict).

Change-Id: I6464eacf9f970cbcc1429a50bd59d59faf262bc6
Closes-Bug: #1743338

commit_message:
Restore interface of Connector

It was changed in a backwards incompatible way. This change corrects
it and issues a deprecation warning on using old arguments.

commit_message:
Add SQL reporter to Zuul experiemental and tripleo pipelines

The Zuul MySQL database is one of the only ways we can get fairly
precise historical metrics for the jobs that run in all the pipelines.

However, we're missing a significant amount of data right now by
leaving out the experiemental, check-tripleo and
check-tripleo-experimental pipelines.

Let's start recording those so we can make informed decisions with
numbers easily in the future.

Change-Id: I0daeff1f6c6d4527cbd17f55c2df242e1ecb8b33

commit_message:
Cinder Tempest plugin tests: Switch to stable interface

All the cinder tempest plugin tests are inherited from tempest/api/volume/base.py
which is not stable class and can be changed anytime by tempest.

One recent case where some changes in base class on tempest side could
have break the cinder tests-
 http://logs.openstack.org/07/522707/3/check/legacy-tempest-dsvm-full-devstack-plugin-ceph/a92cd60/logs/testr_results.html.gz

This commit switch cinder tests to use test.py which is stable interface
for plugin and create a base class with commonly used function & variable.

Change-Id: I0edda1fa23aed0b3d25691d5f4440a7234decc9a
Closes-Bug: #1734821
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-tempest-plugin refs/changes/18/533118/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
remove -s alias for --sort-columns

Cliff normally uses short option name aliases which are global
in to the CLI.  We want commands to not use them due to the
limited number and ease of collision.  However this one
was already in use by a well-known plugin so we will not take it.

Change-Id: Id348dad450b52716b82d7852d6378ecc48808f26
Closes-Bug: #1743578
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cliff refs/changes/71/534771/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(dhellmann): Setting the conflict handler to # 'resolve' means that options registered last "win" in # owning a given option name. This lets commands override # short options that might be used by formatter # extensions, for example. See bug # https://bugs.launchpad.net/python-cliff/+bug/1743578 for # details. conflict_handler='resolve',

commit_message:
Fix ingress bw limit for OVS DPDK ports

For OVS based DPDK ports ingress bandwidth limit is now implemented
using egress-policer qos type.
Additionally limit values are set in other_config of QoS because there
is no queue used in this case.

This patch moves also helper methods used to conversion between
bytes and bits and between bits and kilobits to neutron.common.utils
to be able to use it also in ovs_lib module.

Change-Id: I94d1e8dfb82df5c602476db8aaa884ae91fecd7f
Closes-Bug: #1724729

commit_message:
Use telemetry-tempest plugin for telemetry projects

* https://review.openstack.org/#/c/532773/ moves the gnocchi, panko,
  aodh, ceilometer tempest tests into telemetry-tempest-plugin
* Let's use it and it is available in RDO:
  https://review.rdoproject.org/r/#/c/11332/

Change-Id: Iee9ca8ff41831849f41cc016a110c7fd933d02d7

commit_message:
Update and add listener stats release notes

Adds a release note for the listener stats feature and updates the release
notes theme to the new openstackdocs theme.

Change-Id: Ia1ba31176b4c84fe7f09d7bdc62f20412875c709

commit_message:
Added rgw_keystone_implicit_tenants to ceph::rgw::keystone

Set to true for private tenant for each new user (1).

1: http://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/radosgw/keystone/

Change-Id: I8e0c08b3ab5812bbd75fdeed176655fefe2c631a
Closes-Bug: 1743602

commit_message:
Minimize nodepool-builder configuration

We can remove a lot of these settings as they don't apply to
nodepool-builders.  Also switch to yaml anchors for
provider.diskimages sections.

Change-Id: I71570c51d2e07d23ddc71ad696ed6b41e6e93ece
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
api-ref: fix the response parameter for multiattach

The multiattach parameter is optional when creating
a volume but is required to be in the response when
showing a volume.

This fixes the parameter usage, renames the parameters
so they are more clear (multiattach_1 was for the response
but was never used), and also adds a note to the multiattach
request parameter about how support is dependent on the volume
type being used to create the volume.

Change-Id: Ifaa29140a8e8a9b8090f33fb83e4bb5c98ee847f

subject: Block attempts to transfer encrypted volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-04 16:58:08.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/unit/test_volume_transfer.py', 'cinder/transfer/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/04d7e2d80d4cfe0d3a2cae477d9e09b6dc1071a2', 'message': "Block attempts to transfer encrypted volumes

Block attempts to transfer encrypted volumes until [1] gets resolved.

[1] documents the fact that encryption keys are not properly transferred
to the new volume owner. Resolving this will be tricky because Key
Managers such as Barbican currently provide no API for transferring
ownership, and Key Manager ACLs are insufficient because they don't
allow the new volume owner to delete the key.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1735285

Related-Bug: #1735285
Change-Id: I5dbeb46adc9da1fce6359a96b981aa8d673d50c4
"}]
commit_message:
Block attempts to transfer encrypted volumes

Block attempts to transfer encrypted volumes until [1] gets resolved.

[1] documents the fact that encryption keys are not properly transferred
to the new volume owner. Resolving this will be tricky because Key
Managers such as Barbican currently provide no API for transferring
ownership, and Key Manager ACLs are insufficient because they don't
allow the new volume owner to delete the key.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1735285

Related-Bug: #1735285
Change-Id: I5dbeb46adc9da1fce6359a96b981aa8d673d50c4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/00/531200/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Mariadb: enable storage ownership management on pod start

This PS enables storage ownership management on pod start, which
is required for some PVC providers/provisioners.

Change-Id: Idb4bd20104815efb241ed163daddf27f8bd2b559

commit_message:
DS8K: block in-use volume to be added to consistency group

In DS8K, adding the in-use volume into consistency group will failed.
Fix this issue by blocking user to add the attached volume into
consistency group.

Change-Id: Id7f0e336183f03c5687389dce0f71c5a773889d6
Closes-Bug: 1742845

commit_message:
Replace hardcoded profile name with _TUNED_PROFILE_NAME_

The *-variables.conf file for tuned is hardcoded for the profile
"cpu-partitioning", which makes other profiles fail, that also need
the isolated_cores variable.

Change-Id: Iaeedfe5d7c501453fd2039b81c1603eff6125ebf

commit_message:
Discover every tag on prepare

With a concurrency of 16, the versioned tag of every image can be
discovered in 30 seconds when running prepare against
trunk.registry.rdoproject.org from far-far-away.

Change-Id: Ia500c425d05487c9246cbce1f6c87c6e70d997e9
Partial-Bug: #1738669
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/15/529215/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: print('%s -> %s' % (image, tag_label)) def discover_image_tags(self, images, tag_from_label=None): image_urls = [self._image_to_url(i) for i in images] # prime self.insecure_registries by testing every image for url in image_urls: self.is_insecure_registry(url.netloc) discover_args = [] for image in images: discover_args.append((image, tag_from_label, self.insecure_registries)) p = multiprocessing.Pool(16) versioned_images = {} for image, versioned_image in p.map(discover_tag_from_inspect, discover_args): versioned_images[image] = versioned_image return versioned_images def discover_tag_from_inspect(args): image, tag_from_label, insecure_registries = args image_url = DockerImageUploader._image_to_url(image) insecure = image_url.netloc in insecure_registries i = DockerImageUploader._inspect(image_url.geturl(), insecure) return image, DockerImageUploader._discover_tag_from_inspect( i, image, tag_from_label)

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-08 17:57:47.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/gate-check-commit.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/ddd7fc847a1abb589b19c5893e362ba16da795e9', 'message': "Define GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT before use

GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT was defined in scripts library and used in
gate-check-commit. When script library is loaded before using in
gate-check-commit, everything is fine. But when gate-check-commit
is doing upgrades, the checkout of previous branch happens before
the loading of the script library, which therefore loads previous

"}]
commit_message:
Define GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT before use

GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT was defined in scripts library and used in
gate-check-commit. When script library is loaded before using in
gate-check-commit, everything is fine. But when gate-check-commit
is doing upgrades, the checkout of previous branch happens before
the loading of the script library, which therefore loads previous
version of the script library which doesn't contain the
GATE_EXIT_RUN_DSTAT environment variable, and therefore the usage
of this variable fails.

Change-Id: Ica58331d8c63d354561aebefd1b1e26dc2b37ffb
(cherry picked from commit f8da4b760ad71e9a559660d9b41414920b8a2b14)

commit_message:
set up governance repo for storyboard

As part of tracking progress on community goals with storyboard, we
want to set up the governance repo so we can have artifacts associated
with it in storyboard.

There is currently no launchpad project for the governance repo, so
there are no bugs to migrate.

Change-Id: I65c44097aedcc304c68155507946e64f9a523702
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

turn off python 3.5 jobs for goal-tools repo

We aren't ready to have these tests running yet.

Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

subject: [bgpvpn_dashboard] Fix bug when a network or router name doesn't exist
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-12 13:59:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn/commit/a6cd462e8cf4e8e9e0bd72669c81814ed0432102', 'message': "[bgpvpn_dashboard] Fix bug when a network or router name doesn't exist

In the popup Update Networks Association a the field network can me empty
when a network have no name. Same thing for the routers.

The fix display the id when name doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I71d4bf3f74997a1d0bf1e84e93d88ac5c22678fc
Closes-Bug:1742948
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-01-15 14:29:33.000000000', 'files': ['bgpvpn_dashboard/dashboards/project/bgpvpn/workflows.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn/commit/2d477cd4bd12593953df5b97c3cfad4ceba9a5bb', 'message': "[bgpvpn_dashboard] Fix bug when a network or router name doesn't exist

In the popup Update Networks Association the field network can be empty
when a network has no name. Same thing for the routers.

Change-Id: I71d4bf3f74997a1d0bf1e84e93d88ac5c22678fc
Closes-Bug:1742948
"}]
commit_message:
[bgpvpn_dashboard] Fix bug when a network or router name doesn't exist

In the popup Update Networks Association the field network can be empty
when a network has no name. Same thing for the routers.

The fix displays the id when name doesn't exist.

Change-Id: I71d4bf3f74997a1d0bf1e84e93d88ac5c22678fc
Closes-Bug:1742948
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/86/533186/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Utility functions for port association tests in tempest
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-16 08:43:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn/commit/fcdb2da3a1efbfb9b61ffd7e3a4c08df25fd49e1', 'message': "Utility functions for port association tests in tempest

Utility functions for tempest tests of L3 BGPVPN port
associations functionality:
- Port security can be now disabled on network level
- Added bgpclient functions to manage port associations
- Utility function to setup ip forwarding in VM
- Utility function to setup alternative ip addres of
  VM's network interface
- Different destination ip can be specified for L3 BGPVPN
  check

commit_message:
Utility functions for port association tests in tempest

Utility functions for tempest tests of L3 BGPVPN port
associations functionality:
- Port security can be now disabled on network level
- Added bgpclient functions to manage port associations
- Utility function to setup ip forwarding in VM
- Utility function to setup alternative ip addres of
  VM's network interface
- Different destination ip can be specified for L3 BGPVPN
  check

Change-Id: I2ba9f41cc612dce3a44f6ca06e4da6a7279ab7d3
Depends-On: I59559aa9efdd42d7730c57d0e72fc12aaf6f6b4d
Depends-On: I3b58506ffa03eb32399d7da4f8fd4cc3be425756
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/86/534186/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH = '/bgpvpn/bgpvpns/%s/port_associations' def create_port_association(self, bgpvpn_id, **kwargs): uri = BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH % bgpvpn_id post_data = {"port_association": kwargs} return self.create_resource(uri, post_data) def update_port_association(self, bgpvpn_id, association_id, **kwargs): uri_pattern = BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH + "/%s" uri = uri_pattern % (bgpvpn_id, association_id) post_data = {"port_association": kwargs} return self.update_resource(uri, post_data) def delete_port_association(self, bgpvpn_id, association_id): uri_pattern = BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH + "/%s" uri = uri_pattern % (bgpvpn_id, association_id) return self.delete_resource(uri) def show_port_association(self, bgpvpn_id, association_id, **fields): uri_pattern = BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH + "/%s" uri = uri_pattern % (bgpvpn_id, association_id) return self.show_resource(uri, **fields) def list_port_associations(self, bgpvpn_id, **filters): uri = BGPVPN_PORT_ASSOCIATION_PATH % bgpvpn_id return self.list_resources(uri, **filters)

commit_message:
requirements.txt: Add PyMySQL dependency for ironic-dbsync

The ironic-dbsync needs the optional PyMySQL dependency from sqlalchemy
otherwise it fails with the following error:

CRITI [ironic] ImportError: No module named pymysql
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/bin/ironic-dbsync", line 10, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/cmd/dbsync.py", line 103, in main
    CONF.command.func()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/cmd/dbsync.py", line 35, in upgrade
     migration.upgrade(CONF.command.revision)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/db/migration.py", line 36, in upgrade
     return get_backend().upgrade(version)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/ironic/db/sqlalchemy/migration.py", line 56, in upgrade
     alembic.command.upgrade(config, revision or 'head')
[...]
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/sqlalchemy/dialects/mysql/pymysql.py", line 49, in dbapi
     return __import__('pymysql')
ImportError: No module named pymysql

Change-Id: Ic56765eeaa708f9006887f35cfb53a2e656ddd3c

commit_message:
Minor follow-up for wait_for_disk tests

Add timeout setting and a note to possibly retool
the tests at some point so we are not explicitly
setting the interval.

Follows up I9134b4cfdf15ba9610b4d1f844e64858d69713a5

Change-Id: I7a12a801551407376dc8c714f5de9f1999774ab3

commit_message:
Release networking-generic-switch 0.4.1

This is the first managed release from the pike branch. The branch
itself was created before n-g-s was moved under bare metal program.
Since we cannot add new projects to existing series, releasing it
as an independent release.

Change-Id: I089a1303971800189eb83b350077512653b95485

commit_message:
Adding new tables for future consumption

In ovsfw code, we've introduced new tables ACCEPTED_EGRESS_TRAFFIC_TABLE,
ACCEPTED_INGRESS_TRAFFIC_TABLE, DROPPED_TRAFFIC_TABLE for future
consumption like logging [1]. This patch adopts that to firewall driver
based OVS, then the issue related to security group logging which is specified
in release note of co-existence patch will be fixed.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/commit/65bde9f769e2ac18cb2684595000f92440f774d9

Co-Authored-By: Chandan Dutta Chowdhury <chandanc@juniper.net>

Change-Id: Ie673de416b67aceb2401d6fb8485dcb4f36a3d07

commit_message:
Apply default firewall group for new VM ports

The default fwg will be applied to all new VM ports within
a project if option auto_association_default_firewall_group
is enabled. This provides a way for a tenant network admin
to define a tenant wide firewall policy that applies to all
new VM ports.

Co-Authored-By: Nguyen Phuong An <AnNP@vn.fujitsu.com>

Partial-Implements: blueprint fwaas-api-2.0
Change-Id: I9e897444cd63e44c3274cdc9efedb35f8b325d1f

commit_message:
Update default value for derive params workflow inputs

This change is to update the default value for derive params
workflow inputs num_phy_cores_per_numa_node_for_pmd
and huge_page_allocation_percentage.
num_phy_cores_per_numa_node_for_pmd default value needs to be reduced
to 1 and cannot use more than 1 because of multi-queues.
huge_page_allocation_percentage default value needs to be reduced
from 90 because in some cases where we do not have enough memory
for some hosts

Change-Id: I8620f07f09337d0d63198c3168fec00f16262a63
Closes-Bug: #1736713

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-08 21:53:03.000000000', 'files': ['guidelines/pagination_filter_sort.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/api-sig/commit/4b569b5e4d74b49b777927d9410d09a43ebf5947', 'message': "Expand note about rfc5988 link header

commit_message:
Expand note about rfc5988 link header

An alternate that is suggested for people who cannot add link sections
to the response body is the RFC 5988 Link header.

Move it to its own section for ease of linking, and change the text from
'can consider' to 'should'.

Also, add a note about API breakage and versioning related to adding
Link headers.

Change-Id: Ide4124513e3328084c53a2122384a4e25ea6c863
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/14/531914/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Pagination Links ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Link Header Alternative ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ If services are not including JSON `Hyper-Schema`_ links in their responses, or if they cannot include them for some reasons, they should return pagination links in the ``Link`` header as defined in :rfc:`5988` and :rfc:`6903`. .. note:: Adding the ``Link`` to responses should not be considered an API contract change that needs a either a minor version bump or a microversion. Because of the nature of HTTP headers and the relationship of REST services with proxies, load balancers and API gateways, HTTP clients must already handle the existence of additional headers that may not be relevant. Consuming pagination is a fundamental operation that is frequently not done on a per-service basis. Requiring a user to undergo a microversion negotiation or minor version is extra per-service work that is both difficult and which carries no value. Users can simply check to see if a Link header exists, and if one does, they can consume the data in it.
deleted_lines: Alternatively, if services are not including JSON `Hyper-Schema`_ links in their responses they can consider using the ``Link`` header as defined in :rfc:`5988` and :rfc:`6903`.

commit_message:
placement: _get_trees_matching_all_resources()

Adds a utility function in nova/objects/resource_provider.py that
returns the set of root_provider_id values representing provider trees
that can COLLECTIVELY satisfy a request for resources.

Change-Id: I8ec2b4c9b0d48263ab13305d0550279bfa2dbe6f
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/531512/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_trees_matching_all(self): """Creates a few provider trees having different inventories and allocations and tests the _get_trees_matching_all() utility function to ensure that only the root provider IDs of matching provider trees are returned. """ # We are setting up 3 trees of providers that looks like this: # # compute node (cn) # / \ # / \ # numa cell 0 numa cell 1 # | | # | | # pf 0 pf 1 for x in ('0', '1', '2'): name = 'cn' + x cn_name = name cn = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( context=self.ctx, uuid=getattr(uuids, name), name=name, ) cn.create() _add_inventory(cn, fields.ResourceClass.VCPU, 16) _add_inventory(cn, fields.ResourceClass.MEMORY_MB, 32768) name = 'cn' + x + '_numa0' numa0_name = name numa_cell0 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( context=self.ctx, uuid=getattr(uuids, name), name=name, parent_provider_uuid=getattr(uuids, cn_name), ) numa_cell0.create() name = 'cn' + x + '_numa1' numa1_name = name numa_cell1 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( context=self.ctx, uuid=getattr(uuids, name), name=name, parent_provider_uuid=getattr(uuids, cn_name), ) numa_cell1.create() name = 'cn' + x + '_numa0_pf0' pf0 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( context=self.ctx, uuid=getattr(uuids, name), name=name, parent_provider_uuid=getattr(uuids, numa0_name), ) pf0.create() _add_inventory(pf0, fields.ResourceClass.SRIOV_NET_VF, 8) name = 'cn' + x + '_numa1_pf1' pf1 = rp_obj.ResourceProvider( context=self.ctx, uuid=getattr(uuids, name), name=name, parent_provider_uuid=getattr(uuids, numa1_name), ) pf1.create() _add_inventory(pf1, fields.ResourceClass.SRIOV_NET_VF, 8) # NOTE(jaypipes): _get_trees_matching_all() expects a dict of resource # class internal identifiers, not string names resources = { fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index( fields.ResourceClass.VCPU): 2, fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index( fields.ResourceClass.MEMORY_MB): 256, fields.ResourceClass.STANDARD.index( fields.ResourceClass.SRIOV_NET_VF): 1, } traits = [] trees = rp_obj._get_trees_matching_all(self.ctx, resources, traits) self.assertEqual(3, len(trees))

commit_message:
Retire craton (1/2)

The development of craton has stopped around March 2017, we can retire
the repositories now.

This is the first step in retiring them.

See also
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-January/126341.html

Change-Id: If620605a9e441e136c51890f33e139edf9bc0f6b

commit_message:
Run tempest executables directly in the venv

This patch simplifies the execution of tempest and related
executables by calling the executable directly rather than
activating the venv first.

Closes-Bug: 1743599
Change-Id: I3bbd05354791010eaebe6c88afad387a283602ce

commit_message:
Add a guideline about use of the service catalog

The service catalog is an essential part of all API interactions,
but it's use is largely freeform (or cargo-culted based on what's in
devstack) Add specific guidlines for the catalogs of the future.

Split out the information from the discoverability document that was
talking about service catalog things and put it here.

Also, update a few examples in the code to be on endpoints that don't
have ports, so that we don't accidentally continue to recommend ports.

Change-Id: I60fe5e32ea895bbdf9508b23983b13b6619b1c4f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/api-sig refs/changes/56/460656/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. _service_catalog: Service Catalog =============== While the `Service Catalog`_ allows for a great deal of flexibility and choice on the part of a deployer, wanton exercise of that choice can make some things much harder on API consumers. This topic document serves to provide guidance on how services should be registered in the `Service Catalog`_ to maximize API consumers' chances of success. See also the topic document on :ref:`compatibility`. See also the topic document on :ref:`discoverability`. See also the topic document on :ref:`consuming-discovery`. .. _unversioned-endpoint-registration: Unversioned Endpoint Registration --------------------------------- It is highly recommended that Cloud Operators register the Unversioned Endpoint for a service in the Keystone Catalog. If they do, the process described in :ref:`consuming-discovery` will be able to be both the most featureful for the API Consumer and the most efficient. .. _preference-for-subpaths: Preference for Subpaths ----------------------- Historically each of the OpenStack services were also given a port. It is strongly recommended to not use those ports and instead use the normal port 443 for https. If multiple API services are to be installed on a single machine, it is highly recommended to use subpaths:: https://api.example.com/compute https://api.example.com/image The rationale behind this recommendation is to ease use for users who may have restrictive port-blocking firewalls in their operating environment. Since the traffic is HTTP traffic and not a different protocol, it is not necessary to distinguish it by port number, and doing so increases the chances that users will have problems connecting to individual API endpoints. .. _service-type-registration: Service Type Registration ------------------------- The ``service-type`` a service is registered into the `Service Catalog`_ with should come from the `OpenStack Service Types Authority`_. There should be one and only one entry for each ``service-type``. On clouds that have already deployed and registered a service in the `Service Catalog`_ with a historical or non-conforming ``service-type``, it is recommended to add an additional entry to the catalog with the correct ``service-type``. It will not break anything to have an additional entry. For example, if the service catalog at example.com contains the following entry: .. code-block:: json { "token": { "catalog": [ { "endpoints": [ { "id": "39dc322ce86c4111b4f06c2eeae0841b", "interface": "public", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" }, { "id": "ec642f27474842e78bf059f6c48f4e99", "interface": "internal", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" }, { "id": "c609fc430175452290b62a4242e8a7e8", "interface": "admin", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" } ], "id": "4363ae44bdf34a3981fde3b823cb9aa2", "type": "volumev2", "name": "cinder" } ], } Some users of example.com may already be counting on the undesirable ``volumev2`` entry. In this case, the deployer should simply add another entry: .. code-block:: json { "token": { "catalog": [ { "endpoints": [ { "id": "39dc322ce86c4111b4f06c2eeae0841b", "interface": "public", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" }, { "id": "ec642f27474842e78bf059f6c48f4e99", "interface": "internal", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" }, { "id": "c609fc430175452290b62a4242e8a7e8", "interface": "admin", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com/v2" } ], "id": "4363ae44bdf34a3981fde3b823cb9aa2", "type": "volumev2", "name": "cinder" } { "endpoints": [ { "id": "39dc322ce86c4111b4f06c2eeae0841c", "interface": "public", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com" }, { "id": "ec642f27474842e78bf059f6c48f4e90", "interface": "internal", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com" }, { "id": "c609fc430175452290b62a4242e8a7e9", "interface": "admin", "region": "Dallas", "url": "https://block-storage.example.com" } ], "id": "4363ae44bdf34a3981fde3b823cb9aa3", "type": "block-storage", "name": "cinder" } ], } .. _clouds-and-regions: Clouds and Regions ------------------ The deployment of a given service for a given region is a self-contained unit. It has no awareness of other regions, or even that it is a region. In fact, the only place that regions actually exist is as metadata about a service's endpoint in the `Service Catalog`_. Since the `Service Catalog`_ is, itself, managed by a service, it is usually desired to have an installation of that service in each region as well. Once there is a keystone in each region, each of those regions are, effectively, completely independent clouds from an API perspective. Without clarity, a user can quickly become confused, so the following terminology is defined and recommendations are made: cloud A logical collection of one or more regions of services. The regions of a ``cloud`` share some logical connection, and it is useful to refer to them as an entity. A user uses the same authentication credentials to access each region of the cloud. region An independent collection of services whose endpoints are registered into the `Service Catalog`_ using the same name. A "customer" has an "account" on a "cloud". That "cloud" has one more more "regions", and each "region" has one more more API services. It is recommended that all clouds have a simple well-known name that can be used to uniquely identify the cloud for API consumers and in the :ref:`cloud_profile`. It is recommended that each region have a simple, unique, well-known name. (see :ref:`region-naming`) It is recommended that service and endpoint information for the services in all regions be registered with the keystones in all regions, if there are per-region keystone installations. It is recommended that a user account be the same in each keystone in a cloud if there are per-region keystone installations. It is recommended that if the deployer prefers to manage user accounts and service catalogs independently in each region, that the deployer treat those as separate clouds with their own name and :ref:`cloud_profile`. There is no recommendation related to shared ``auth_url`` for all regions or per-region ``auth_url``. Both are fine, and both are accounted for in the :ref:`cloud_profile`. .. _region-naming: Region Naming ------------- As OpenStack Region Names are primarily metadata that exists in the `Service Catalog`_, and in a cloud deployment with only one region it can be very tempting to disregard setting a region name and just use ``RegionOne``. This is strongly discouraged. The primary unit of connection for an OpenStack API consumer is a Region at a given Cloud. Just as a cloud should have a human understandable logical name (see :ref:`cloud_profile`), so too should a region. It is recommended that deployers give each region a simple logical name that communicates something about location. If the deployer is not feeling creative, `IATA Airport Codes`_ have proven to be popular, simple and descriptive. Good examples: * dallas # likely located in Dallas, TX, USA * dallas01 # likely the first region located in Dallas, TX, USA * dfw # likely located in Dallas, TX, USA * us-east # likely located somewhere in the Eastern part of USA * antarctica01 # likely the first region located in antarctica * collider01 # likely located down in the first collider at CERN * advertising # likely located over in the advertising department * ftc-a3 # likley located in building a3 at our Fort Collins campus Bad Examples: * RegionOne # The devstack defaults aren't always the right idea * cloud # no, really? * region # I'd like some "dinner" for dinner tonight please .. _OpenStack Service Types Authority: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/service-types-authority/ .. _Service Catalog: https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/identity/v3/?expanded=get-service-catalog-detail .. _IATA Airport Codes: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Air_Transport_Association_airport_code

https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html#howto-update-legacy-jobs

commit_message:
Fix starting hive failure in Ubuntu xenial

The mysql configuration file name and directory change in
Ubuntu 16.04. my.cnf becomes an entry for mysql configuration.
The new file locates here:
  "/etc/mysql/mysql.conf.d/mysqld.cnf"

Change-Id: I8f70589cfc904a7d30081172b313ad8e30914935
Closes-Bug: #1738124

commit_message:
Create backup from volume snapshot

The test validates backup creation of a volume snapshot.

Change-Id: I5347225323553370a3646a0d2b27ace55e0544f2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/33/530033/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @decorators.idempotent_id('26061e9e-285a-4c60-b464-aedca02b318f') def test_create_backup_from_snapshot(self): # Create volume and snapshot volume = self.create_volume() snapshot = self.create_snapshot(volume_id=volume['id']) # Create a backup for volume snapshot backup = self.create_backup(volume_id=volume['id'], snapshot_id=snapshot['id']) # Verify the backup was created from the volume snapshot backup_info = self.backups_client.show_backup(backup['id'])['backup'] self.assertEqual(volume['id'], backup_info['volume_id']) self.assertEqual(snapshot['id'], backup_info['snapshot_id'])

subject: Don't make async_pendings during object expiration
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-10 03:29:50.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/523fa2a59c8ea4ae5c2afaf22d50fe02cbd65c79', 'message': "Don't make async_pendings during object expiration

After deleting an object, the object expirer deletes the corresponding
row from the expirer queue by making DELETE requests directly to the
container servers. The same thing happens after attempting to delete
an object, but failing because the object has already been deleted. If
the DELETE requests fail, then the expirer will encounter that row
again on its next pass and retry the DELETE at that time. Therefore,
it is not necessary for the object server to write an async_pending
for that queue row's deletion.

Currently, however, each object server does write such an
async_pending. Given Rc container replicas and Ro object replicas, the
net result is (Ro + 1) * Rc DELETE requests to container servers. With
3 replicas of everything, that's 12 requests to container servers for
each deleted object. With 10+4 EC, that's 45 requests.

This commit makes the object server write no async_pendings for DELETE
requests coming from the object expirer. This reduces the number of
container server requests to Rc (typically 3), all issued directly
from the object expirer.

Change-Id: Icd63c80c73f864d2561e745c3154fbfda02bd0cc

commit_message:
Don't make async_pendings during object expiration

After deleting an object, the object expirer deletes the corresponding
row from the expirer queue by making DELETE requests directly to the
container servers. The same thing happens after attempting to delete
an object, but failing because the object has already been deleted. If
the DELETE requests fail, then the expirer will encounter that row
again on its next pass and retry the DELETE at that time. Therefore,
it is not necessary for the object server to write an async_pending
for that queue row's deletion.

Currently, however, two of the object servers do write such
async_pendings. Given Rc container replicas, that's 2 * Rc updates
from async_pendings and another Rc from the object expirer
directly. Given a typical Rc of 3, that's 9 container updates per
expiring object.

This commit makes the object server write no async_pendings for DELETE
requests coming from the object expirer. This reduces the number of
container server requests to Rc (typically 3), all issued directly
from the object expirer.

Closes-Bug: 1076202
Change-Id: Icd63c80c73f864d2561e745c3154fbfda02bd0cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/83/532383/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import errno import os # run the expirer again after replication def test_expirer_doesnt_make_async_pendings(self): # The object expirer cleans up its own queue. The inner loop # basically looks like this: # # for obj in stuff_to_delete: # delete_the_object(obj) # remove_the_queue_entry(obj) # # By default, upon receipt of a DELETE request for an expiring # object, the object servers will create async_pending records to # clean the expirer queue. Since the expirer cleans its own queue, # this is unnecessary. The expirer can make requests in such a way # tha the object server does not write out any async pendings; this # test asserts that this is the case. def gather_async_pendings(onodes): async_pendings = [] for onode in onodes: async_pending_dir = os.path.join( self.device_dir('', onode), 'async_pending') try: ap_dirs = os.listdir(async_pending_dir) except OSError as err: if err.errno == errno.ENOENT: pass else: raise else: for ap_dir in ap_dirs: ap_dir_fullpath = os.path.join( async_pending_dir, ap_dir) async_pendings.extend([ os.path.join(ap_dir_fullpath, ent) for ent in os.listdir(ap_dir_fullpath)]) return async_pendings # Make an expiring object obj_brain = BrainSplitter(self.url, self.token, self.container_name, self.object_name, 'object', self.policy) obj_brain.put_container() now = time.time() delete_at = int(now + 2.0) obj_brain.put_object({'X-Delete-At': str(delete_at), 'X-Timestamp': Timestamp(now).normal}) time.sleep(2.0) # make sure auto-created expirer-queue container gets in the account # listing so the expirer can find it Manager(['container-updater']).once() opart, onodes = self.object_ring.get_nodes( self.account, self.container_name, self.object_name) pendings_before = gather_async_pendings(onodes) # expire the object Manager(['object-expirer']).once() pendings_after = gather_async_pendings(onodes) self.assertEqual(pendings_after, pendings_before)
deleted_lines: # run the expirier again after replication

We want to avoid loading a nested stack in memory wherever possible, since
that is known to cause memory high-water-mark issues. The grouputils
functions are among the worst offenders at doing this. Some of the data
that they return is easily obtained from an RPC call to
list_stack_resources, so swap out the implementations using nested().

Rather than simply add more utility functions, a GroupInspector class is
created that can cache the data returned. In future this will allow groups

nested Stack.)

commit_message:
Avoid loading nested stack in some grouputils functions

We want to avoid loading a nested stack in memory wherever possible, since
that is known to cause memory high-water-mark issues. The grouputils
functions are among the worst offenders at doing this. Some of the data
that they return is easily obtained from an RPC call to
list_stack_resources, so swap out the implementations using nested().

Rather than simply add more utility functions, a GroupInspector class is
created that can cache the data returned. In future this will allow groups
that need to access multiple functions from the grouputils to do so without
making multiple RPC calls. (Previously, the data was cached in the group's
nested Stack.)

Change-Id: Icd35d91bce30ee36d9592b0516767ef273a9f34d
Partial-Bug: #1731349
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/68/530968/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.engine import status from heat.engine import template from heat.rpc import api as rpc_api class GroupInspector(object): """A class for returning data about a scaling group. All data is fetched over RPC, and the group's stack is never loaded into memory locally. Data is cached so it will be fetched only once. To refresh the data, create a new GroupInspector. """ def __init__(self, context, rpc_client, group_identity): """Initialise with a context, rpc_client, and stack identifier.""" self._context = context self._rpc_client = rpc_client self._identity = group_identity self._member_data = None self._template_data = None @classmethod def from_parent_resource(cls, parent_resource): """Create a GroupInspector from a parent resource. This is a convenience method to instantiate a GroupInspector from a Heat StackResource object. """ return cls(parent_resource.context, parent_resource.rpc_client(), parent_resource.nested_identifier()) def _get_member_data(self): if self._identity is None: return [] if self._member_data is None: rsrcs = self._rpc_client.list_stack_resources(self._context, dict(self._identity)) def sort_key(r): return (r[rpc_api.RES_STATUS] != status.ResourceStatus.FAILED, r[rpc_api.RES_CREATION_TIME], r[rpc_api.RES_NAME]) self._member_data = sorted(rsrcs, key=sort_key) return self._member_data def _members(self, include_failed): return (r for r in self._get_member_data() if (include_failed or r[rpc_api.RES_STATUS] != status.ResourceStatus.FAILED)) def size(self, include_failed): """Return the size of the group. If include_failed is False, only members not in a FAILED state will be counted. """ return sum(1 for m in self._members(include_failed)) def member_names(self, include_failed): """Return an iterator over the names of the group members If include_failed is False, only members not in a FAILED state will be included. """ return (m[rpc_api.RES_NAME] for m in self._members(include_failed)) def _get_template_data(self): if self._identity is None: return None if self._template_data is None: self._template_data = self._rpc_client.get_template(self._context, self._identity) return self._template_data def template(self): """Return a Template object representing the group's current template. Note that this does *not* include any environment data. """ data = self._get_template_data() if data is None: return None return template.Template(data) The size excludes failed members by default; set include_failed=True to get the total size. return GroupInspector.from_parent_resource(group).size(include_failed) inspector = GroupInspector.from_parent_resource(group) return list(inspector.member_names(include_failed=False)) The List is sorted first by created_time then by name. If include_failed is set, failed members will be put first in the List sorted by created_time then by name. inspector = GroupInspector.from_parent_resource(group) template = inspector.template() if template is None: return [] definitions = template.resource_definitions(None) return [(name, definitions[name]) for name in inspector.member_names(include_failed=include_failed)]
deleted_lines: The size exclude failed members default, set include_failed=True to get total size. if group.nested(): resources = [r for r in six.itervalues(group.nested()) if include_failed or r.status != r.FAILED] return len(resources) else: return 0 return [r.name for r in get_members(group)] The List is sorted first by created_time then by name. If include_failed is set, failed members will be put first in the List sorted by created_time then by name. return [(resource.name, resource.t) for resource in get_members(group, include_failed)]

deleted_lines: - hosts: all name: Autoconverted job legacy-trove-tox-apiexamples from old job gate-trove-tox-apiexamples-ubuntu-xenial tasks: - name: Ensure legacy workspace directory file: path: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' state: directory - shell: cmd: | set -e set -x CLONEMAP=`mktemp` REQS_DIR=`mktemp -d` function cleanup { mkdir -p $WORKSPACE rm -rf $CLONEMAP $REQS_DIR } trap cleanup EXIT cat > $CLONEMAP << EOF clonemap: - name: $ZUUL_PROJECT dest: . EOF # zuul cloner works poorly if there are 2 names that are the # same in here. if [[ "$ZUUL_PROJECT" != "openstack/requirements" ]]; then cat >> $CLONEMAP << EOF - name: openstack/requirements dest: $REQS_DIR EOF fi /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner -m $CLONEMAP --cache-dir /opt/git \ git://git.openstack.org $ZUUL_PROJECT openstack/requirements # REQS_DIR is not set for openstack/requirements and there is also # no need to copy in this case. if [[ "$ZUUL_PROJECT" != "openstack/requirements" ]]; then cp $REQS_DIR/upper-constraints.txt ./ fi executable: /bin/bash chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}' - shell: cmd: /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/install-distro-packages.sh chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}' - shell: cmd: | if [ -x tools/test-setup.sh ] ; then tools/test-setup.sh fi chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}' - shell: cmd: | set -x sudo rm -f /etc/sudoers.d/zuul # Prove that general sudo access is actually revoked ! sudo -n true executable: /bin/bash chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}' - shell: cmd: /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/run-tox.sh apiexamples chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}' - shell: cmd: | OUT=`git ls-files --other --exclude-standard --directory` if [ -z "$OUT" ]; then echo "No extra files created during test." exit 0 else echo "The following un-ignored files were created during the test:" echo "$OUT" exit 0 # TODO: change to 1 to fail tests. fi executable: /bin/bash chdir: '{{ ansible_user_dir }}/workspace' environment: '{{ zuul | zuul_legacy_vars }}'

Add the option of specifying a custom overcloud stack name

This change adds the option to specify the overcloud stack name
when doing the update/upgrade.
